item.title: Captured Saddam Faces Tough Interrogation (AP)
item.description: AP - American troops seized a haggard Saddam Hussein in a cramped hole near one of his palaces Sunday, a humiliating fate for one of history's most brutal dictators. U.S. officials said Saddam faces tough interrogations — about ongoing attacks against occupation forces, and his regime's banned weapons programs.

item.title: Chamber Beneath Mud Hut Leads to Hussein (AP)
item.description: AP - When darkness fell, the Americans moved into position, 600 of them, from infantrymen to elite special forces. Their target: two houses in this rural village of orange, lemon and palm groves. Someone big was inside, they were told.

item.title: Close Calls Preceded U.S. Raid for Saddam (AP)
item.description: AP - Eight months and four days after the fall of Baghdad, it fell to soldiers of the 4th Infantry Division and a secretive team of commandos to pry Saddam Hussein from a hole in the ground far smaller than the craters made by U.S. bombs that missed him on the war's opening night.

item.title: Saddam's Capture Gives Bush Huge Boost (AP)
item.description: AP - Saddam Hussein's capture lifted a huge political weight from President Bush after months of rising casualties and growing doubts about his handling of Iraq. Around the world, it sent a thundering message of America's resolve to prevail in the war against terrorism.

item.title: Thousands Attend Sen. Paul Simon Memorial (AP)
item.description: AP - Former Sen. Paul Simon was honored Sunday in a memorial service filled with dignitaries who paid tribute to the popular, low-key senator as a tireless advocate for the oppressed.

item.title: N. Korea Rejects U.S. Nuke Crisis Remedy (AP)
item.description: AP - North Korea on Monday rejected a U.S.-backed proposal on ending a crisis over its nuclear weapons development, and it warned that Washington's "strategy of delaying talks" would only prompt the communist government to accelerate the program.

item.title: Scientists Agonized Over Flu Vaccine (AP)
item.description: AP - Late last winter, a committee of vaccine experts designing this season's flu shot considered their choices. They had two, and both seemed bad.

item.title: Sandra Diaz-Twine Wins $1M on 'Survivor' (AP)
item.description: AP - In a "Survivor" contest packed with villains and indelible characters, Sandra Diaz-Twine, a mother of two from the Northwest, had the staying power to win the television game.

item.title: 'Something's Gotta Give' Rules Box Office (AP)
item.description: AP - Love among older adults conquered the box office as Jack Nicholson and Diane Keaton's romance "Something's Gotta Give" debuted in the top spot with $17 million.

item.title: Panthers Clinch NFC South Title (AP)
item.description: AP - The Carolina Panthers never win anything easily, and that includes the NFC South title they finally clinched Sunday.

item.title: Bush Hails Saddam's 'Rat-Like' Capture (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - President Bush hailed the "rat-like" capture of Saddam Hussein in a pit hideout and vowed to stamp out attacks on U.S.-led forces in Iraq as he presses his case for re-election.

item.title: Army Tells of Pulling Bewildered Saddam from Hole (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - When U.S. forces pulled Saddam Hussein from a hole in the ground behind a two-room shepherd's hut, they were within sight of the former Iraqi president's lavish palaces in his hometown of Tikrit.

item.title: Report: Saddam Tells Interrogators 'No WMD' (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Saddam Hussein denied during the initial interrogation after his capture that Iraq possessed weapons of mass destruction, Time magazine reported on Sunday.

item.title: Captured Iraqi Tip Led to Final Push on Saddam (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - One Iraqi taken into custody and interrogated in recent days gave U.S. authorities the lead that captured Saddam Hussein, ending an intense manhunt for the former Iraqi leader since the fall of Baghdad in April, U.S. officials said on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Forces Uncover Iraqi Ex-Leader Near Home Town (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - BAGHDAD, Dec. 14 -- Former Iraqi president Saddam Hussein was captured without a shot Saturday night by American soldiers who discovered him hiding in the dark of a tiny, underground burrow near his home town, U.S. military officials said on Sunday.

item.title: When Focus Shifted Beyond Inner Circle, U.S. Got a Vital Clue (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - BAGHDAD, Dec. 14 -- Thirty-eight weeks after the United States began stalking Saddam Hussein with an arsenal of lethal force, technology and coercion, it fell to a soldier with a spade to flush the fallen leader from a hole.

item.title: No Gloating as Bush Lauds 'Hopeful Day' (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - President Bush welcomed the capture of Saddam Hussein with a spare and brief address to the nation that refrained from gloating over some of the best news his administration -- and the country -- have had in eight months.

item.title: Americans Celebrate Capture of the 'Big Fish' (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - The capture of Saddam Hussein that elated U.S. troops in Iraq, was greeted on the streets of America on Sunday with a sense of relief that the end of the occupation might finally be in sight and that violent resistance would abate.

item.title: In Baghdad, Celebration and Mockery of a Captured Leader (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - As the news spread and gained credibility, Iraqis poured into the streets in many neighborhoods to show their support.

item.title: Without Firing a Shot, U.S. Forces Detain Deposed Leader (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - Coalition troops discovered Saddam Hussein hiding in a hole below a farm house located in Adwar, 10 miles from Tikrit.

item.title: Union vs. Union on Iowa Campaign Battleground (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - Iowa has become the epicenter of a fierce labor battle between supporters of Richard A. Gephardt and Howard Dean.

item.title: World Trade Center Fireproofing Tests Suggest a Wider Safety Problem (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - Hundreds of buildings with fireproofing similar to that used in the trade center could be more prone to structural damage during major fires than previously thought.

item.title: European Union Cannot Reach Deal on Constitution (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - The leaders of 25 current and imminent members of the European Union ended the summit today divided over how to apportion power among large and small states.

item.title: Woman Claims Thurmond As Father (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - A 78-year-old retired Los Angeles schoolteacher said she is breaking a lifetime of silence to announce that she is the illegitimate mixed-race daughter of former U.S. senator James Strom Thurmond (R-S.C.), once the nation's leading segregationist. In an interview, the woman said that Thurmond privately acknowledged her as his daughter and provided financial support since 1941.

item.title: Congress pushes for larger military (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Members of Congress from both parties are pushing for the first significant increase in the size of the active-duty military in 16 years, despite resistance from the Pentagon.

item.title: Flu takes hold coast to coast (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Influenza completed its west-to-east sweep like a storm front by week's end, sowing chills and fever nationwide and hammering 24 states with widespread illness - nearly twice as many as last week, U.S. health officials said Thursday.

item.title: No welcome mat for crematories (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The dead may rest in peace, but their bodies are causing quite a stir.

item.title: Report: $2B hasn't stopped gaps in bioterror readiness (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Despite a $2 billion federal investment, the nation's public health system is only marginally better prepared today to handle a bioterrorism attack or other health emergency than it was in 2001, a new report shows.

item.title: Dean Working to Be Seen as Foreign Policy Centrist (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - Democratic presidential candidate Howard Dean said he would offer a package deal to North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons programs and he embraced an unofficial peace plan that establishes the borders of a Palestinian state -- breaking dramatically with the approaches of the Bush administration.

item.title: Dean's campaign like no other (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Howard Dean rose from long shot to front-runner in the Democratic presidential race by outworking his rivals at conventional politics and at the same time taking risks that would be unthinkable to most politicians.
